CANADA
Kamsack, Sask.,
17th September, 1937.

Dear Sir:

I beg to request authority for the expenditure of $165.00 for the school year 1st September 1937 to 30th June, 1938. This is the usual amount allowed each year for the Cote Day School for food for the mid-day meals and meals of the children who stay at the school nights if their homes are too far distant for them to travel to and from school daily.

Your obedient servant,

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.
September 21, 1937.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of September 17th, you may expend an amount not exceeding $165.00 in purchase of mid-day meal supplies for the pupils of the Cote Indian Day School during the academic year 1937-38.

Yours truly,

T.R.M. MacInnes,
Secretary.

J.F.B. Ostendorf, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kamsack, Sask.

Ottawa,
June 25, 1938.

Dear Sir:

The Department is in receipt of a report from Inspector Robertson stating that the Cote Day School is badly in need of paint, both on the exterior and the interior.

In preparing our appropriation for the current fiscal year it was found possible to include an amount of $300.00 for repairs, improvements and new equipment necessary at this school.

Please let me have a report stating how you consider this amount could be spent to the best advantage.

If the material for the work recommended by you costs more than $50.00 it will be necessary for you to send full particulars in order that purchase of same may be made through our Purchasing Branch.

If it is not possible to employ Indians to do the necessary work both at the Keys and the Cote Schools you should let me know the tradesmen required and the approximate cost of the labour at each school separately.

Yours truly,

Dear Mr. Bryant:

I note with much concern the recent decision of
the Department to reduce the hot noon meal appropriation
for Cote Day School from $165 to $75.

While I realize the necessity for economy in
order to further our war effort, yet I consider that the
reduction is much too drastic in view of present crop
conditions on the reserve, which as you know are the poorest
in many years. The potato crop in the school garden is only
about 1/3 of normal and of poor quality while other
vegetables are correspondingly poor, and it will be necessary
to purchase a considerable quantity of potatoes to provide
sufficient for the children and for seed next spring.

The attendance is expected to be considerably
above last year which will necessitate a greater quantity of
food and I do not feel justified in decreasing the amount per
child as they are always ravenously hungry for the noon meal,
indicating that this is the only substantial meal they receive
during the day.

With the appropriation cut to $75 it means that
the meat and soup portion of the meal will have to be almost
eliminated, as the meat bill alone last year amounted to
approximately $70. The fact that the former practice of
keeping a number of boarding pupils during the week has been
discontinued does not decrease the meat requirement as no
meat or soup was served to these pupils for breakfast or
supper.

I also note that the Department speak of having
the noon meal served during the cold weather only. Now this
would mean much less work for the staff but I would strongly
advise against this plan as I feel that many children would
suffer from malnutrition if they were denied the hot midday
meal and were forced to subsist on bannock and tea. The
fact that the cost of living has risen during the past year
also makes it increasingly difficult to carry on with a
reduced allowance.

I should be very glad, Mr. Bryant, if you would bring these facts to the knowledge of the Department.

Sincerely yours,

(Sgd.) L.L. Dobbin,
Teacher.
Dear Sir:

I wish to refer you to your letter File #117-2-5 of September 6th regarding a reduction in the amount to be expended in the purchase of provisions for Cote Indian Day School for the coming year.

I might say that one or two Indian families are not taking very kindly to the idea of discontinuing keeping their children at the school from Monday until Friday, and if the noon meal is discontinued except in cold weather it would add to the difficulties.

I am enclosing Mr. Dobbins's letter for your perusal, which I think explains the situation clearly and accurately. There is no doubt the noon meal is much appreciated and very helpful to the children. Meat prices are also higher this year which also applies to many lines of groceries. Under the circumstances I would respectfully recommend that the matter be reconsidered and that at least $100.00 be allowed for midday lunch purposes at the Cote School for the academic year 1940-41.

Yours truly,

J. L. Bryant,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

Re Yours, # 117-2-5, Dec. 11, 1940.

In explanation of the three items referred to in your letter of the above date with regard to Voucher # 254, Mr. Seeder gives the following:

"Inspecting Heating Plant";

"Transportation of Brick Layer and Helper";
The repairs were taken out a day before the work was commenced on it and therefore the helpers had to use their own transportation means to get to school and charged for the same.

"Cartage from town to Agency";
Mr. Seeder has no truck of his own and had to hire one.

A receipt is enclosed herewith covering the freight and cartage charges as per your request. He wishes to have it returned to him after it has served your purpose.

I wish to inform you that while at the Pelly Agency, Kamsack, I visited the above institution.

Upon checking over the register I found that there were 28 children on the roll, of which 19 were present at the time of my visit. The average attendance is around 20.

Building and Grounds

I noticed that everything around the School and premises was in good order and the building and fences were in good state of repair. I consider that the teacher, Mr. L.L. Dobbin, is an exceptionally able man. He takes a great interest in gardening and the pupils maintain a garden in the Summer that is a credit to anybody. I noticed in going through the basement of the School that he had potatoes and all kinds of vegetables they had raised last Summer. I also discovered that sewing was being taught to the girls by Mrs. Dobbin.

Children

I spoke to the children in their classrooms and although they all live at home, this being a Day School, they appeared to be healthy and well clad.

Problems

Here are a few of the problems Mr. Dobbin brought to my attention.

(1) Milk - As you are aware, this School is situated only a few hundred yards from the Agency and in the past they have been obtaining milk from the Agency as several cows were kept there but under the new regulations we are disposing of some of the cows, therefore as Agent Bryant, who was with me, stated, they cannot expect to get all the milk they require. There is no stable at the School and I advised Mr. Dobbin that I could ask for a cow but I did not know whether the Department would supply this or not. Also, if one were supplied I advised him that he could keep it at the Agency barn as there would be lots of room there but he would have to look after the animal himself.

Transportation - There is also.......
(2) Transportation - There is also the transportation problem in Winter. The School is situated 6 miles from town and having no stable they do not keep a horse. They therefore have to depend on transportation from the Agency or by hiring an Indian. I made it quite clear to Mr. Dobbin that we could not guarantee to let him have a horse or a team from the Agency to go into town when he wanted to but we would co-operate with him wherever possible because you can readily understand that under the new regulations only two teams are kept at the Agency, one for the Farming Instructor and one for the Agent. Of course this problem only presents itself during the Winter when there is a lot of snow. At the present time they are able to get back and forth with a car as there is practically no snow there. I just thought I would let you know that this was brought up during my visit because it was evidently Mr. Dobbin's idea that the Agent would have to furnish him with transportation.

(3) Water

- The water is also a great problem here. This has to be hauled from St. Philips, a distance of 6 miles and this has been carried by the Labourer at the Agency. Now we are dispensing with the services of the Labourer and therefore arrangements will have to be made to haul the water. We are keeping the two tanks the water was hauled in and the School Branch will be charged for their portion of the expense of engaging someone to haul the water. I would, however, recommend that a 50 bbl. water tank be put in the basement of the school so that they can save more rain water and I am herewith attaching a Requisition for this. If this is allowed I can arrange for the installation.

Yours truly,

M. Christenson,
General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 12th instant with reference to your recent visit to the Cote Bay School.

It is not the practice of the Department to supply milk to teachers of Indian day schools and consequently it is unnecessary to make any arrangements for Mr. Dobbin. He will have to make his own arrangements regarding his supply of milk.

What has been said above applies to transportation of the teacher from the school to the town. In this case also Mr. Dobbin will have to make his own arrangements.

Secretary.
Dear Sir:

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter No. 117-2-1 of the 21st instant in connection with the Cote Improved Indian Day School and I note that it is not the practice of the Department to supply milk to the teacher of an Indian Day School.

In reply I wish to say that the milk in question was not for the School teacher, it was for the children who are attending the School, and when Mr. Dobbin was speaking about a cow he did not have himself in mind at all.

I also note what you have to say about the transportation of the teacher from the School to the town, that is, he will have to make his own arrangements. I just want to inform you here that people in Western Canada do not treat their neighbors in the manner you suggest, that is that the teacher will have to do without milk and if he wants to go to town he will just have to make the best arrangements possible. This School was built 27 years ago and is situated right beside the Agency. Ever since it was built the people at the Agency have tried to co-operate in every way and help the School along. You, I know, do not realize how lonely it is to be stranded on an Indian Reserve 6 miles from the nearest white neighbor. Naturally the Agency Staff, which consists of three white families, can make it so much more pleasant for the teacher and his wife when everyone is agreeable. Therefore every Agent who has been there has supplied the School with all the milk they required for the children that could be spared, even if it is not a very great amount. The same thing applies in connection with the teacher from the School getting into town once in a while. When I was there we had no cars but we always made it possible some way or another for the two women who were there at that time to get into Kamsack when they could not get an Indian to take them in. Also the people at the Agency have always brought their mail out to them in addition to what groceries and other supplies they needed from town.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA, Ont.

I have read over..........................
I have just read over my letter to you and wish to say further that I was not asking for a horse for the teacher, I was just telling you about the conversation that took place between myself and the teacher.

Regarding the water used at the School, every drop has been hauled by the Labourer at the Agency with the exception of rain water, and that is why I asked for an extra tank in order to be able to preserve more rain water than at the present time. The School has a large roof surface and if we had another barrel they could probably save enough water in the Summer to have sufficient water for scrubbing, etc., and it would only be necessary to haul the drinking water. This has to be hauled a distance of 6 miles and when we make arrangements in the Spring with some Indian to haul water for the School and the Agency we will advise you what the cost will be to the School. Remember, for 27 years you have been getting off without paying anything. In the meantime I want you to give consideration to the tank that was requested.

Yours truly,

M. Christianson,
MC/ed General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Dear Sir:

In connection with casual labour for the different Agencies in Saskatchewan, Agent Bryant has submitted the estimated cost of casual labour in the Pelly Agency which amounts to $599.50.

I have just returned from Kamsack and while there I discussed this matter with Mr. Bryant. You will note that a great deal of this amount is for hauling water and putting up ice, etc. Under the item of $120.00 for hauling water for the Agency and school, one third of this, namely $40.00, should be charged to the school. There is also an amount of $25.00 included for fencing at the school.

The amount of water that will have to be hauled for the Agency cistern depends on the amount of rainfall during the Summer and from all indications it looks as if we are going to have plenty of rain this year. During the time I spent at Pelly last week it rained practically all the time.

The water situation here is no worse than when I went out to this same Agency twenty-eight years ago. At that time I got permission to put down a well just below the barn. We struck water at 37' but went down another 13', making the well 50' deep in all. This was a board well, 24", cribbed with planks, and the pump we used in it was an old wooden type; therefore the cost was not very extensive. However, this is what has happened. At the 37' level, when putting down the well, we struck a layer of gravel and sand, and it was from this sand and gravel that the water came. The sand and gravel continually filtering down in the well finally filled it up and closed off the water supply, and I do not suppose that a well has been put down since. The water was not fit for human consumption but was alright for cattle and horses.

In view of the above I presume that the water is still there only it has not been tapped since. However, this is only a guess on my part. I would think that it would pay us to put down another 50' well and I see no reason why we should not.

The Secretary
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ont.,

strike water. While I was
strike water. While I was at the Agency I located the approximate place where I put down the well 28 years ago. At that time we did not have cisterns in the houses, and in fact the present Agency house was built by me while I was there. We hauled water for washing purposes from the creek west of the Agency, which is a distance of about half a mile but during the dry years this creek was dry. However, there is water in it once more at the present time. To obtain water for drinking and domestic use we put up ice during the winter and each family kept a barrel tank in the kitchen. By keeping this tank filled with ice it melted fast enough to supply our needs. The same method was followed at the school. They have sufficient tanks in the basement to store rain water for all domestic use and ice would only have to be hauled for human consumption. If this plan were followed an ice house would have to be erected for the school next winter and probably the same thing would have to be done at the Agency as at present they keep their ice in a shed. This is hardly the proper place to store ice.

Mr. Bryant has promised to get me a price on putting down a well at the Agency as I am sure there are some machines still at work in the vicinity of Ramsack, and I shall get in touch with you when I hear from him.

Some items in Mr. Bryant's statement of expenditure for casual labour come under freight. Another item comes under roads, and the matter of cleaning chimneys would come under repairs to buildings. Putting on storm windows would also come under repairs to buildings. There is also the question of whether the employees should plough their own gardens, or are we responsible for this?

Yours truly,

Sgd M. Christianson,

Dear Sir:

Re Cote Day School Telephone:

The Misses Corner and Rogers, teacher and matron have approached me about having their residence connected by telephone to the line and the exchange so that they could make any emergency calls directly from the residence instead of having to run over to the Agency every time they find it necessary. As it happens there are times when the office facilities are not available due to us being closed here, and I think it is quite necessary that this facility be made available for them.

There is one strand of wire already connecting the school and the agent's house, but another strand must be put on in order to be able to call the central. The total cost of connecting the school and the wire will cost approximately $12.00

Kindly advise if I may proceed with having this work done.

Yours truly,

J. L. Bryant,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa,
September 11, 1942.

Dear Sir:

Re: Cote Day School telephone

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 7th instant, in which you intimate that a request has reached you from the teachers of the above-noted school for the installation of a telephone in the teachers' residence.

The records here indicate that we have not, at any time, paid for the installation of telephones in teachers' residences and only in one or two exceptional cases have we paid for the installation of electricity. In view of the policy that has been followed, I hesitate to make an exception in this case. We are, however, as you know, experiencing the utmost difficulty in securing the teachers necessary to operate our schools. I am disposed to think, therefore, in view of the comparatively small amount of money involved, that you might assist the teachers to install this particular telephone. It should be definitely understood, however, that the Department is not committing itself to such expenditures at other schools from which requisitions for such installations may be received in the future.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir:

Re Mid-day meals for Cote and Key Day Schools:

In previous years our allotment for mid-day meals for Cote Day School was $100.00 and for Key Day School $50.00. Since, the prices of the food products have gone up considerably. Meat, the Indian staple diet, has more than doubled in price, while all other products have gone up from 30% to 80%. The amounts allotted for noon day meals would hardly be adequate, and it would be very much appreciated if the Department would grant an extra allowance to compensate for the rise. It has been suggested that Key be allowed $75.00 and Cote, $150.00.

Kindly advise me as to the amounts made available.

Yours truly,

J. L. Bryant,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa,
October 24, 1942.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 17th instant, it has been decided to allow an amount of $110.00 at the Cote Day School and an amount of $60.00 at the Key Day School for purchase of supplies for midday meal purposes during the current academic year. I am not certain if school gardens were cultivated at the schools during the past summer but, if not, they should be next year. It is very important that vegetables should be available to be used for midday meal purposes. Their use will not only save money but is very advisable for dietary reasons.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Indian Agent,

R.A. Hoey, Esq., Supt. Welfare & Training, Ottawa.

Re Cote pay school

It has been very difficult to heat the School room during very cold weather and I have had Mr Barrie of Pelly check up and he recommends some repairs that he estimates will cost $39.25 for labour and material. His letter is attached.

There are also some minor repairs necessary at the school such as doors, windows, steps into the school and railings on the landings, door locks, and electric light switches, also three outhouses should be repaired. I would estimate that the total cost will be approximately $30.00. I have already had the light switches and wiring put in order.

I wrote to Mr Christianson about the furnace and other repairs and he advised that the matter be taken up direct with the department.

J.L. Bryant,

Indian Agent.
EX'D A

Ottawa, September 22, 1943.

Mr. J. L. Bryant, Indian Agent, Kamsack, Sask.
Re: Cote Indian Day School

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 18th instant, in which you state that repairs are necessary at the above-noted school. It is noted that these repairs will cost approximately $69.00.

I must express regret that the need for these repairs has not been brought to the attention of the Department until this comparatively late date. It is of the utmost importance that repairs at our Indian day schools should be undertaken and completed during the regular vacation period. You are authorized, therefore, to take steps necessary to have these repairs undertaken and completed at the earliest possible date.

I am returning herewith the quotation received by you from J. S. Barrie.

R. A. Hoey,

August 5th, 1944.

R.A. Hoey, Esq., Supt. Welfare & Training, Indian Affairs, Ottawa.

Re: Cote Day School

Considerable repair work of a minor nature, such as windows, screens, screen doors, steps, toilets, etc. should be undertaken this month before school opens. The interior of the school room has not been done over for several years, and the woodwork should be varnished. Some of the floors upstairs also require a filler coat and a coat of paint or varnish.

I would estimate that with Indian labour the cost for labour and material would be approximately $150.00. Much more could be done but this will put the building in fair shape for this year.

Some repair work should be done on the furnace and pipes but there is no tinsmith available in the district and it would appear that this work will have to be deferred until a later date. The material will include glass, lumber, screen wire, paint and varnish, and could be purchased locally as required.

J.L. Bryant,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa,

Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ont.

Re Mid Day Meal Allowances for Cote and Key day Schools. 1945/46 Term.

The teachers of the above two schools wish to be advised as to what amounts are available for them for mid day meals they serve to the Indian children in attendance.

Meat, which is the staple item in making soups and broths served in this way costs much more than it used to before the war and the amounts usually made available for this purpose in the past two years made meal planning for the persons in charge a very hard task. I would recommend that the Department increase the allotment to about $150.00 for Cote and $75.00 for Key.

J. L. Bryant,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, August 17, 1945.

Mr. J. L. Bryant, Indian Agent,
Kamsack, Sask.

I have your letter of the 10th instant, with reference to the amounts available for midday meals at the Cote and Key Indian Day Schools.

For the academic year 1945-46 the Department is prepared to allow the same amounts as last year, namely, $110.00 at the Cote School and $60.00 at the Key School.

We are not discontinuing the making of allowances for midday meals, but it is reasonable to expect that in view of the payment of family allowances the children will have better food and should bring to the school more food than formerly for their midday lunch. Under these circumstances, the Department is not inclined to grant the increase that you suggest.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Cote Indian Day School,
Kamsack, Sask.,
March 21, 1946.

Mr. J. L. Bryant,
Pelly Agency,
KAMSACK, Sask.

Dear Mr. Bryant:

I quite understand that there is a shortage of food all over the earth and we must all do our share in saving, but nevertheless I would like to make a request that the food allowance from the Department for this school be increased by $30/- or at least raised to its former level of $125/-

The improvements the British made in India only served to increase its population and they are still poor. In the same way the Family Allowance has served to increase our numbers in school attendance, so that we have twice the number we had last year. 200 days with an average of at least 22 will mean 4466 meals.

It was decided, was it not, not to do away with this noon meal in Indian Day Schools, and judging by my own experience of a rural school and a long walk morning and evening, I think that was wise. These children are looking much healthier and much more full of vigor than if they spent the day on a piece of bannock. They have a very simple meal here at noon. In fact we do not begin to use all the coupons on the permits for sugar, butter and meat allowed us by the Wartime Prices and Trade board. But even in this well-regulated Canada prices are high.

We find our finances strained to meet this exigency for they will continue to get the same amount of food. We should be very grateful indeed if our request were favourably considered.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]
Teacher.
Kamsack, Saskatchewan,
March 22, 1946.

Philip Phelan Esq.,
Chief, Training Division,
Indian Affairs Branch, OTTAWA.

I am attaching herewith a letter received from Miss Robertson, Cote Day School Teacher, wherein she requests an increase of the noon day meal allowance of $30.00 if possible, but that at least $125.00 be allowed for the academic year 1945-1946.

There is no doubt there has been considerable increase in school attendance, and that much more food is now required for the noon day meal than in previous years.

It has never been the custom at Cote Day school for the children to bring lunches, and personally I think it is much the most satisfactory arrangement, as long as the allowance is sufficient to cover the cost. Now all the children get a good hot wholesome meal regardless of home conditions, and the teacher has no bother in looking after lunch boxes.

I trust that you will favourably consider this slight increase for this year, then if necessary some other arrangement can be worked out for the next term.

J.L. Bryant,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, March 27, 1946.

Mr. J. L. Bryant, Indian Agent,
Kamsack, Saskatchewan

With reference to your letter of the 22nd instant, the Department will allow an additional amount of $30.00 for midday meal purposes at the Cote School for the current academic year. It should be distinctly understood that in granting this increased amount it is not to form a precedent for future years.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Re Cote Day School Mid-day meals allowance
1944-45:

The attached voucher #72 covers the meat supplied to the above school during the 1944-45 school year which has been inadvertently overlooked by Mr. Olfman, the butcher. It was only when the clerk checked accounts with him that it was discovered that the account has never been paid. It amounted to $48.58, but Miss Robertson, the teacher gave a personal cheque in the amount of $32.59 reducing it to $15.99. She did this realizing that the account encumbered for that purpose may have been closed out and hoping that she could help to have this account settled.

I do not know if we should expect the teachers to provide supplies for the school out of their own pocket and I am sure she would appreciate it very much if she were reimbursed.

J. L. Bryant,
Indian Agent.

Kamsack, Saskatchewan.

Agent
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Re: Mid Day Meal Allowance for Cote and Key Day Schools 1946-47 Term.

The teachers of the above named schools wish to be advised as to what amounts are available for them for midday meals they serve to the Indian children in attendance.

Meat, which is the stable item in making soups and broths served in this way cost much more than it used to previous the war and the amounts usually made available for this purpose in the past two years made meal planning for the person in charge a very hard task, also due to a larger attendance I would recommend the same allotment as last year namely $140.00 for Cote and $75.00 For Key Bay Schools.

J. L. Bryant.
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, 15 October 1946.

Mr. J.L. Bryant, Indian Agent,
KAMSACK, Sask.

With reference to your letter of the 7th instant, the Department will allow an amount of $140.00 for the academic year 1946-47 to provide a hot lunch for the children attending the Cote Day School.

An amount of $75.00 will be allowed at the Key Day School for the same purpose.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Re: Cote Day School.

The work of interior decorating the ground floor of Cote School, room, dining room, kitchen, and living room has been completed by Mr. Turnbull at a cost of approximately $350.00.

Mr. Turnbull has agreed to do at least part of the upstairs at an estimated cost of $183.00. This would include two bedrooms that are in use and hallways stairs etc. There is considerable plastering to be done and if possible this should be done this fall. There has been nothing done on the interior of this building for many years and it is all very dirty and in poor condition.

I have allowed Mr. Turnbull to proceed with the work which I trust will meet with your approval.

J. L. Bryant,
Indian Agent.

Attached herewith is a requisition for septic tank, bath etc. for Cote Day School residence. The tender covers material and all labour in connection with the construction and installation.

DATE April 17th, 1948
MEMORANDUM

Re: Cote Day School, Pelley Indian Agency, Kamsack, Saskatchewan

During a recent trip to Punnichy and Kamsack, Heating Engineer inspected the heating system at the above, and the following report and recommendations result from his survey.

The Cote Day School is situated at the Pelley Agency, approximately five miles north of Kamsack; and contains one classroom, a sewing room, and a teachers' living quarters, consisting of a kitchen, living room, four bedrooms and a bathroom. The building was erected in 1915 and appears to be structurally sound and in good condition. At the time of the inspection, new plumbing and a water supply system was being installed.

The building is equipped with a gravity warm air heating system which does not function satisfactorily. The furnace is a wood burning type and while it may have been considered large enough for the original requirements, as far as heat output is concerned the piping distribution system evidences questionable design. This is borne out by the fact that all attempts to improve the distribution of heat have proved to be unsuccessful; and the teaching staff reported that they have experienced continual discomfort due to low temperatures within the building.

The character of the building, its shape and size, all tend to make it an extremely difficult proposition to heat by a gravity warm air system. The furnace shows definite signs of wear and tear and no purpose would be served by attempting repairs.

It is our recommendation that the present heating system be removed and replaced with a forced warm air system. When instructions are received to proceed with the design, and when the drawings and specifications have been executed, it will be possible to provide a fairly close estimate of the cost. In the meantime, it is felt that an amount of $1500.00 to $2000.00 should be sufficient to carry out this project.

Chief Engineer.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,

Mr. Hargreaves of the engineering staff inspected the heating system at this school and advised a new furnace and also that the ceiling and outside walls of the class room be insulated. Mr. Hargreaves has no doubt made a report to you in this regard. He did not give me an estimate of the cost. Before a new furnace is installed the cement basement floor should be repaired at a cost of approximately $150.00.

This is a well constructed building generally in good repair, but the heating system has never been satisfactory. In very cold weather it is almost impossible to heat the class room. In fact it is quite common to see the children working in their overcoats in order to keep warm.

I would strongly recommend that the new furnace and insulation be attended to before fall.

J. L. Bryant,

Regina, July 9th, 1948.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

Mrs. Menzies, of Regina, who is active in the Women's Missionary Society of the United Church of Canada, informs me that her Church is supplying a new car for the use of their Missionaries at the Cote Reserve in their work amongst the Indians.

Apparently Mrs. Menzies has information to the effect that a car purchased in this manner is not subject to sales tax and education tax. Please advise me whether or not this is a fact, as I have heard nothing in connection therewith.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.
Colonel B.F. Neary,
Superintendent of Indian Education,
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA - Ontario.

Dear Colonel Neary -

During my visit to Saskatchewan I arrived at the Cote Reserve during 'Treaty' week. It was a great experience to see 104 wigwams housing the Indians - a most colourful sight and everyone seemed to be enjoying the experience.

As you know, we have an excellent teacher and Matron in the Cote School but our Matron is handicapped in her visiting because of transportation and our Society has placed in its estimate sufficient money to purchase a car. In a letter from the teacher, Miss Winnifred Johnson, it is her understanding that Government employees have priority in the purchase of cars and she also believes there is a tax reduction as well.

We are now in a position to purchase this car and we would appreciate your assistance if a reduction and priority can be arranged. The type of car which we would desire would be a small one and high enough in build to ride the ruts over the Indian trails.

We should appreciate hearing from you in this regard.

Yours sincerely,

Mrs. C. Maxwell Loveys
Home Mission Executive Secretary.

I wish to refer to your letter of July 28th, and August 6th, 1948, regarding the obtaining of prices for supplying a new heating system for Cote Bay School.

I went to Yerxton on August 2nd, and interviewed all three plumbing and tinsmith firms, W. H. Carter, Fred Steel and E. G. Lang & Co. of that city, but all had more work contracted for than they could complete this year unless they are able to obtain more skilled help. E. G. Lang & Co. have had an add in several papers for over three months for a tinsmith and have not had one applicant. I also called on Taylor & Co. in Roblin, they have three tinsmiths employed and also have more work arranged for than they can handle this season.

M. Finnie of Kamsack, is sending in his tender today. There has been a few days delay as he had to wait to get prices on the furnace and material from his wholesaler in Winnipeg.

It is possible that there may be some firm in Dauphin, Manitoba, that would submit a tender, but this appears very doubtful as there is so much building going on in all districts. However, I expect to be at Timberton this week and will go on to Dauphin, and find out what the prospects are. Mr. Finnie is a good workman, is a local man and his tender should not be higher than an outside firm, if it were possible to get someone to submit a tender.

I have advised Mr. Finnie that I expect other firms to submit tenders for the work.

J. D. Bryant,
Superintendent.

Attached is a copy of a tender submitted by A.M. Finnie of Kamsack, Saskatchewan. We have forwarded the certified cheque of $249.30 to the Treasury Branch.

Today we received a telegram from Mr. Hargreaves, who is again in the west, and he reports that he considers the Finnie tender is not unreasonable and recommends immediate acceptance of it.

We would appreciate it if the Minister would approve the acceptance of the tender mentioned.

[Signature]

Director

Attached is Voucher No.51 covering material and labour rewiring electrical circuit in connection with the installation of the new furnace at Cote Day School.

When this furnace was installed the 1/2 horse power motor driving the blower was connected as instructed to the 110 Volt circuit, by so doing causing the line voltage to drop to such an extent that motor would only run in low gear, resulting in overheating and there was danger in it being burned out if left on the present hook up. Due to the continuous running of this motor in low gear the remaining lights in the school became very poor.

To overcome this a third wire had to be strung from the Transformer at the Agency to the school a distance of about 1/3 of a mile and changing Transformer connections from 110 Volt to 225 Volt by omitting grounding. Under this hook up blower motor is now working satisfactory. A further lead was taken of the 225 Volt line at the school using ground hook up, and by so doing, bringing voltage down to 110 to operate the water pump for the water system. A third lead in the same manner was installed for the remaining lights in the building.

In many cases heavier wire and conductors had to be used also electrical meter had to be exchanged and new switch and fuse boxes installed.

The school has been quite comfortable since the installation of the new furnace.

I trust that the necessary rewiring and extra labour and material will meet with your approval, and I would recommend that the above voucher be paid.

J. L. Bryant,
Superintendent.

Regina, March 11th, 1949.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

It is my opinion that the amount of money made available for midday meals for the children attending the Cote Indian Day School should be somewhat increased if it is the policy of the Department to continue supplying a reasonably adequate midday meal as has always been the custom at that school.

There are now 61 children on the roll, and the average attendance, although not as good as it should be at the present time because of a great deal of Whooping Cough and Influenza, can be expected to be at least 50. $140.00 a year does not go very far toward supplying a midday meal for 50 children for 300 days.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

The new heating plants at the Cote Day School and the St. Philip's Residential School, in the Pelly Agency, have both been installed and are giving excellent service.

Apparently neither of the accounts has been paid in full, and cannot be, until the work has been inspected by Mr. Hargreaves. If it is not possible for Mr. Hargreaves to visit these two schools to inspect the work at an early date perhaps it could be arranged through the Department of Public Works to have Mr. John Ramage, their engineer at Saskatoon, inspect them. I am sure Mr. Ramage would be quite willing to do it if so instructed, and it is desirable to complete payment as soon as possible.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

Memorandum

Re: Cote Indian Day School, Kamsack, Saskatchewan.

With reference to Major MacKay's memorandum of March 19th bearing your marginal notation, together with a copy of Regional Supervisor Ostrander's letter dated March 11th in connection with the above, you are advised as follows.

It was expected that our Mr. Hargreaves would call at the above on one of his western trips to the area, but the circumstances in connection with his recent trip to Sioux Lookout and Renora did not permit the extra time required to visit Kamsack.

Mr. Ostrander reports that the new heating system is "giving excellent service". Ordinarily for a job of this relatively small size and type, it would not be considered necessary to send an officer from Ottawa to make a final inspection.

If the Indian Affairs Branch are satisfied with Mr. Ostrander's statement, partially quoted in the preceding paragraph, we see no reason why they should not make final payment to Finnie, the Contractor. No funds were transferred to this Division covering this work.

In accepting the work they should call on the Contractor to provide a written guarantee that the system will heat the building evenly from 20 degrees below zero outside temperature to 70 degrees inside.

We are in receipt of a letter from Mr. Finnie to which was attached a drawing showing several changes which he made to the layout prepared by this Division. Mr. Finnie has taken more liberties with the design than would have been permitted if he had requested authority before carrying out the changes. It is for this reason that it is felt necessary to advise the Indian Affairs Branch to ask for his written guarantee.

Again, it is felt unnecessary to have Mr. Ostrander request Mr. Ramage to inspect this work. Mr. Ramage is a Public Works official stationed in Saskatoon, and it is felt that it would be unfair to ask him to inspect work over which he has had no previous connection or control.

Chief Engineer.

I have for acknowledgement your letter of July 6, and September 19, in connection with the erection of a coal bin and repairs to the cement floor at Cote Day School.

The expenditure for this work including gravel, cement, lumber and labour amounted to $282.05.

The soil in this school basement is alkali and the part of the floor that was done last year with ordinary cement was not entirely satisfactory. This year we used Kalicute cement specially prepared for use in alkaline soils. This cement costs $2.45 a sack and 40 sacks were used as a thin coat was also put on over the part that was done last year.

The school building is being painted at the present time and there were a number of places such as doors, window frames steps, railings etc., that needed minor repairs, and also three toilets that required three windows, a new door and new covers at the back where the refuse box is removed for cleaning purposes and I took the liberty of having these repairs done while I had a carpenter building a coal bin and more especially in order to get the work done ahead of the painter.

It is regretted that the expenditure exceeds the estimate but I think I can assure you that the cost of fuel for the school for this fiscal year will be approximately $300.00 less than provided for in our 1949-50 estimates.

J. L. Bryant,
Superintendent.
Pelly Agency.

Col. Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Indian Education
Indian Affairs Branch.
Ottawa, Ont.

Re: Cote Day School.

Hot noon day lunches at Cote Day School have not been provided for, for this academic year, but hot cocoa has been served since the weather became cold. There are 70 pupils on the roll with 65 in attendance this month. The majority of the children bring very good lunches but the lunches are often frozen when they arrive at the school and as the school rooms are pretty well packed to capacity the children have no suitable place to put their lunch pails. Lunches in the cloak rooms very occasionally disappear and at noon the child finds most of his lunch gone, and some of the lunches are still frozen at noon.

The school staff put in quite a large garden this year and have ample supplies of potatoes, onions, turnips, carrots etc. to provide a good hot meal, but meat is required for soup and stews and something for desert and a hot drink, milk cocoa etc.

Under the circumstances could at least $100.00 be provided for this purpose in order that good hot lunches could be provided during the balance of the winter. Miss Mac Donald the School Matron and the teachers are willing and anxious to provide these. They feel that a great number of the children that drive or walk 3 miles or more to school really need a good hot lunch at noon.

Cote Band Council would be willing to vote some of their Band Funds for this purpose but as we have a few children from Keesekoose Reserve attending this school there would possibly be complaints from some of the Cote Band members if the cost of the lunch was paid from Cote Band Funds. Children from two families that live at the extreme south end of Keesekoose Reserve and live within a mile and a half of Cote School are the children referred to.

Personally I am very much in favour of a hot noon day lunch for all the children during the winter months. The attendance is better as occasionally children are kept home when supplies are short and a suitable lunch cannot be prepared for them. The children do not like to bring out their lunch pails if their lunches are not up to the standard of the other children. Many of the children have a very light breakfast very early in the morning, and require a substantial noon day meal every school day for best results.

Any assistance that could be provided for this purpose would be much appreciated.

J. L. Bryant,
Supt. Indian Agency.

Re: Cote Indian Day School

We have your letter of the 21st instant with reference to serving a midday meal at the above school.

In recent years the Department has only provided funds for serving a hot drink and vitaminized biscuits, and it has been generally understood that the meal at noon should only be served between November 1st and March 31st of the following year. With the payment of Family Allowances, it is reasonable to suppose that the Indians are in a better position to supply a lunch for their children. Our experience in other agencies proves that this is a fact.

Several years ago we provided funds for a midday meal, but it was found that in many cases the serving of this meal seriously interfered with the conduct of the school, as too much time was spent in preparing the meal and cleaning up afterwards.

If the Cote Band are prepared to provide funds to augment the present midday meal, the usual resolution should be passed and forwarded to the Trust Division for their decision. In a few places funds are raised from other sources, but the Department is not prepared to increase the amount that we are allowing at the present time.

April 6th, 1901

Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 3rd of March, I beg to say I have followed instructions out faithfully, both as regards the medicine given to me, the report of which I have already sent to the Agent & personal cleanliness. I have had the houses scrubbed twice a week, & themselves kept clean & tidy, for without that medicine will be useless. I suppose the Dr comes sometimes. I send him once myself, & that is the only time I have seen him. So I give the medicine to the best of my ability, & with good results, as I suppose you have been.

I wish to say a few words for myself, the Indians will never keep themselves or houses clean without personal supervision & as the extra work involves a great deal of time after school hours, I have made application for $10 ten dollars per month so one as ever been bound to show them how to clean their houses, so they were very dirty & consequently disease & sickness is constantly among them, another cause of sickness is want. I was rounded up a final inspection yesterday, before I send this & in only two houses had they a little flour, but were terribly up the bones of dead animals which died from tuberculosis, this should be discontinued, they told me it was all they had to eat.

The Sanitarian has read out any report to the Indians, & they want me to say that they will carry out any instructions, they also wish me to ask for...
A little more for their children's dinner, the little ones are not strong, they often come to school without any breakfast, then I give them one of the slices of bread allowed, & the other for dinner. If I had something to make soup for them sometimes & a little tea I could help them very much, the death rate among children is increasing.

Yr obedient servant

[Signature]

Acting Chief X Neenquah

Acting Councillor X Crow Buffalo

April 24th 1909.

Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your letter dated March 23rd, 1909 No 117006/1, and I beg to submit the following report dealing with my work as teacher of the Day Stars school.

With reference to my gardening operations I may say that I have a fairly large garden in connection which I divide into plots and apportion them to the pupils who are old enough to do the work.

The children plant these plots under my direction with carrots, onions, turnips and potatoes and in order to stimulate their interest I give a small prize to the child who takes the best care of its plot.

About one half an hour is devoted to work in the garden each day. I have no particular time set apart for this work but when I notice that the pupils are becoming tired and restless in the class room I take them out to the garden and the change of work is a relaxation for them.

The products of the garden are stored in my cellar in the fall and during the cold weather I give them vegetable soup for their dinner in addition to their allowance of biscuits. In this way they receive some actual benefit from their work.

There is considerable rivalry amongst the children as to who will have the best garden and I consider that the effect is beneficial.

The Secretary

Department of Indian Affairs

OTTAWA
With reference to the methods used to obtain a good average attendance I may say that I try to make the school as attractive as possible for the children and believe that they anxious to attend.

When any of the parents persistently keep their children away from the school I notify the Indian Agent who has always given me his active support.

During the summer months when at times the Indians are encamped at a distance from the school one of the larger boys usually brings the rest of the pupils with a team of horses and a wagon.

The parents take a great deal of interest in my work and visit the school frequently. I also visit the children at their homes more especially if there is any sickness among them and in this way become acquainted with the younger ones who when they reach school age are no trouble.

The Day Star band are all pagan Indians and follow the Indian mode of living. They object to having the boys hair cut and dress them in blanket coats and leggings. I have respected their wishes in this respect and have not interfered with their mode of dressing, and have thus avoided what would have been a detriment to the attendance.

I receive enough print from the Agent each year to provide the girls with overall aprons which they leave at the school and only wear while there. This enables them to present a clean and tidy appearance.

I trust that the foregoing report will be found satisfactory and will be glad to submit any further information if required.

I beg to thank the Department for their kindly recognition of my work and for the increase to my salary.

Your obedient servant

REPORT
on the Work and General Condition of
Day Star's Indian School
Punnichy, Sask.

1. INSTRUCTION

The progress during the two and a half years I have been in charge of this School has been steady; the children are more retentive and their powers of observation are considerably increased, resulting in a keener and deeper interest in their work. I would not suggest that any abnormal advance in knowledge has been made, but consider the above acquisitions, to which I have given considerable (and I trust not undue) attention, to be a foundation upon which good results may be built.

Each standard is well up to the schedule prescribed by the Department, in Reading, Writing, Spelling, Arithmetic and Scripture, which statement I emphasize in view of the report of Inspector Graham on his last visit to the school in March 1916, and which appeared in the last "Blue Book" which fell into my hands. I refer to his remark, "There is room for improvement", and of which no one is more conscious than I; but this statement appears to suggest that the work is below the average, and however this may compare with other schools I maintain that it is far in advance of that two years ago.

On this subject I would ask you to bear in mind two facts in considering my report; First,-that all the Standards were advanced since the Inspector's previous visit, the boys then in Standard I being now in Standard III; Secondly,-the excessive shyness of the Indian child in presence of a stranger, making it almost impossible to obtain a satisfactory idea of their progress by a surprise examination. This failing I have spent much time in trying to overcome, and am succeeding well by encouraging the children to visit the house and take notice of, and enquire about, objects which excite their interest: Much useful instruction is given in this way.

In Military Drill and Calisthenics they are very proficient, and enjoy the exercises. In music slow progress is being made, singing being, apparently quite new to them, and in this their nervousness is most noticeable, it being quite difficult to exhibit their capabilities before strangers.
GARDEN.

Although part of the course of instruction this subject is one to which I desire to call your special attention.

Due to the difficulty in getting the ground fenced it was impossible for me, during the first two seasons, to do more than superintend the cultivation of a few vegetables in a small piece of ground protected only by ordinary chicken wire. This was very unsatisfactory, and gave no scope for instruction in the proper care of a garden, so I have this year, with the assistance of the Agent, a barbed wire enclosure sufficient to allow each child in Standards II & III a plot under his own care, in addition to which all of them assist in the care and cultivation of the remainder of the garden.

I am particularly pleased to report the results under this heading as I have just returned from a short holiday and, although the children are camping some distance from the school during the vacation, I found the whole garden free from weeds, the paths clean and straight and everything in perfect order. I think that this result will support me in my remarks under suggestions, below.

ATTENDANCE

The average is fairly good, the low average during last winter being accounted for by sickness. When once the start is made the children like to come but there are still two or three on the reserve who have reached school age but are kept at home by the undue apprehensiveness of the parents concerning their health. These cases I feel, as also the following, might be efficiently dealt with under suggestion 7. I refer here to the only boy which I have any trouble with as regards attendance. This boy (No.40) absents himself for days at a time, hiding from his parents and often leaving the reservation. As I understand that there is at present no means of compelling attendance I submit my idea for meeting these cases for your consideration.

I am still endeavouring to arrange for some children from Poor Man's reserve to attend the school, and trust that you will be able to give me some assistance under suggestion 8/

HEALTH

No serious cases of sickness have occurred amongst the children during my residence here but in January and November of last year (1916) an epidemic of Grippe necessitated the closing of the school for nine days in all.
Owing to developments in two cases at this time I felt it expedient to drive to town for medical assistance, and much delay was caused through the requirements of the Department that I should first obtain the consent of the Agent. I mention this only to emphasize my request under suggestion 2.

There was a case of Eczema of the face which I shall mention in order to call attention to the need of some means of isolation in extreme cases.

This boy, another from this reserve, suffering from a painfully visible form of scrofula, were mixing freely with the crowd on race day at Punnichy, causing annoyance to those they approached and much comment on their being allowed to expose themselves in public, and although I was approached on the subject I had to confess that I knew of no authority by which I could act.

The children are clean, tidy, contented and happy at school, but better accommodation is badly needed for washing, and the reception of outdoor garments, towels and washing utensils.

MEALS.

Under this heading I would refer you to my report under the new regulation of provisions used during the month of June and your letter in reply dated July 18th No. 11706/1.

My remarks on this report were called forth in the belief that there must be some misunderstanding in view of the Agent's letter which accompanied the blank forms, stating that the mid-day meal must not exceed seven cents per day per pupil; This taking the form of a censure, I referred to my books and discovered that during two years and seven months 4058 meals had been served on supplies from the Agency, during the same period, of 134½ lb. Rice, 21½ lb. Tea, and 975 lb. Biscuits, costing the Department, at the highest estimation less than 3½ per meal. In addition to this allowance, with the help of members of the Church the children receive Sugar, Syrup or preserves daily and meat twice a week. It was always my intention, as suggested in your letter above, to continue these meals, but at the same time they are a considerable drain on my income and if the Department can increase the allowance to the value of 7½ per head as your Agent intimates it would be exceedingly helpful.

Owing to the lack of accommodation in the school room, and the impossibility of inculcating Christian habits and cleanliness whilst eating their dinners from the desks, I have allotted a space in the house where the children now dine, the elder girls preparing the meal and doing all the neces-
all the necessary washing and cleaning up. My table accommodation, however, is very inadequate for the number of diners and I should much appreciate an allowance of sufficient lumber to make a table of sufficient strength and size for this purpose.

BUILDINGS

The School building is in a fair state of repair with the exception of the steps and platform, which are quite worn out; It was suggested, however by Mr. Graham when here last year that this should be left alone until your decision re porch or vestibule, the erection of which he promised to recommend. A coat of paint put on last summer has improved the appearance of the School both inside and out. Great inconvenience has been caused by the absence of any form of screen for the summer months, I have, however now wired two of the windows, and hope by next summer that the Department will be able to assist us by the addition of a screen door.

The House needs a little attention in order to save what may prove a heavy expense later on. The painting of the outside, which was postponed last year at the time the School was done, on account of the expense cannot be much longer delayed without injury to the building, but the foundation near the cellar opening needs immediate attention where the drippings from the eaves have soaked through; Twice during my tenancy the cellar walls have caved in through this soakage, and the rafters are becoming so rotten that the floor above will not be safe unless something is done to preserve it. A slight expense would save further trouble, and the eave troughs, when placed in position, will prevent further trouble in this direction.

The old building, formerly the house and school, now abandoned, is being gradually demolished, what little lumber of any use being used up in improvements on the school room and house now in use, but I have up to the present been compelled to use part as stable; I am expecting to have a new stable erected before the Fall and the Agent has advised me that he is submitting this matter for your consideration as regards the expense, as it is necessary that he should have accommodation for his team when visiting here in the winter and the old school is now too dilapidated for further use.

Although much of my work on behalf of the Diocese is done beyond the
beyond the school limits I might appear to be trespassing upon the prerogative of the Agent in making any mention of conditions as they appear to me amongst the adult population, but as regards that part of the work for which I am responsible I am pleased to say that a growing interest is shown in the Sunday services and in religious matters generally. I am also commencing an evening class for the younger men who are at last realizing that the age of 15 is not necessarily synonymous with compulsory cessation of study as seems to have been the prevalent idea.

I make the following SUGGESTIONS in the belief that if carried out they will tend to greater efficiency for reasons given in my report under the various headings:

(1) GARDEN; That a supply of necessary Garden tools for the use of the children be authorised by the Department.

(2) HEALTH; That the Teacher be authorised to summon Medical Aid.

(3) " That a small supply of Medical Appliances suitable for First Aid should be kept at the School, the Agency being 13 miles away.

(4) MEALS; That if the same rations as allowed to Farm Instructors were allowed to the Teacher the present strain of providing a sufficient midday meal would be relieved.

(5) " That the Agent might with advantage consult the Teacher as to requirements when making his annual estimate of the amount of provisions needed for the school.

(6) ATTENDANCE; That on account of the average of attendance being reduced by absenteeism during seeding and harvesting, the Teacher have authority to close the School at such times and reduce the Mid-summer holidays in proportion.

(7) " That one of the Indian men be appointed Truant Officer. There are two or three intelligent reliable men on the Reserve by whom this appointment would be appreciated and to whom it would give additional interest in the work of the school through the sense of responsibility entailed and would I think effectively meet both cases referred to in my report.

(8) " That assistance in rations or otherwise be given to those willing to board children from Poor Man's Reserve wishing to attend this school.
In conclusion I would ask you to give your consideration to my request for Lumber mentioned in my report on Meals and also for two Gates for the School Fence, both of which I will submit through the Agent in due course.

I also desire to mention the TELEPHONE which will be completed shortly within about two miles of the School. It is not necessary for me to urge what an inestimable boon this would be in such an isolated spot, especially in cases of sickness. I have mentioned the matter to the Agent who states that he is at present unaware of your intentions concerning its installation, and seems to fear urging it on account of expense, but I am convinced that much of this would be saved by the voluntary help which the men on the Reserve would render in view of the benefits to be derived.

The following would be helpful and much appreciated:

- A copy of the Act concerning Indian Schools
- A copy of the Blue Book, when issued
- Any publication on Wild Flowers, Birds & Weeds
- Any information possible regarding the Treaty with the Indians on this Reserve.

All of which I submit with all confidence that your Department will understand that I have only the welfare of the Indians at heart in anything that I have reported or suggested, and with sincere thanks for the ready assistance which I have hitherto received from you.

Extract from Inspector's Report on the DAY STAR'S Indian School, dated Sept. 15/22.

Mr. Turner is an earnest worker and has the interests of his pupils at heart. Through lack of training very much of the work is misdirected. There is too much work involving mere parrot-like repetition of exercises; practically no attempt to awaken the self activity of the pupils. As a result very few can express themselves in English that can be understood. They are trained to follow and repeat what the teacher says without the essential mental effort to make the instruction truly educational.

The pupils are not showing the desired progress. This is, in my opinion, chiefly due to two causes, namely,

(1) The teacher has no training for primary work.

(2) The pupils are not in the physical condition essential to successful mental application.

The general trend of the teaching and instruction is not the type needed. The natural interests and conditions under which the pupils live are not sufficiently taken into account. The work has no connection with their real life and, as a result, becomes dry, pedantic and dead.

Mr. Turner has the missionary spirit and the right attitude but he should be induced to train for the work of teaching, otherwise it becomes a work of groping in the dark for results.

B. Hjalmarson,
Insp.

Sir:-

I beg to attach hereto a report of an inspection on the various schools in the Touchwood Agency, which was made by Mr. Inspector Christiansen.

The first school reported on is Fishing Lake, situated on the Fishing Lake Reserve. This school is under the auspices of the Anglican Church and is taught by Mr. Laws. The report of the Inspector shows that good work is being done here. He also comments on the buildings, which are very fine and are kept in good shape.

The report on the Muscowequan Boarding School is very encouraging and shows that the Principal has the work well in hand. There is a good farm here and the work in connection with it is well done.

March 19th, 1926

Dear Mr. Hjalmarson,

I am enclosing a copy of the note received from the Indian Agent re John Kapayeequa (commonly known as John Kapay).

I will write you a statement of the whole affair.

On December 15th, George Kapay came to school about 9:30 am and asked if he might take away his boy, John, to dig skunk in the mountain. As this man had two other sons at home, I did not deem this a sufficiently reasonable excuse to permit him to leave school without the consent and knowledge of the Indian Agent. George thereupon expressed his opinion of the teacher in forcible and obscene English. I ordered him to leave the building, and
reported the matter to the Indian Agent who informed me that nothing could be done with this man for this offence.

When the January term opened John was troublesome. He started to undermine the morale of the school. Gradually the children seemed to lose all power to speak English! I watched them very carefully. This culminated on Feb. 25th.

For winter use, I had allowed the boys to make a stack of wood about six feet east of the school building. During the noon lunch hour the boys knocked most of this wood down. About 12:45 a boy knocked at the door and asked if it were school time. Mr. Jolley answered the door and then gave the following message, "Mr. Jolley says that the boys are to stack the wood they have knocked down. It is to be stacked near the fence."
Donald Machinini delivered the message. John Kapay was standing on the school steps. No boy moved to obey my order. I waited until 1 pm. I then went to the yard, sounded the "Fall In" and told the boys to obey my order. In the meantime I started school work with the girls. In about five minutes I heard a boy crying. It was Donald Machinini. He was being beaten (with a stick) by another boy. I went outside and demanded, "Why do you beat Donald?" The boy replied, "He is lazy. John told me to beat him." John laughed and passed an insolent remark in Cree. I watched him for several minutes and, as he showed no signs of behaving properly, I told him to go home and wait until the Agent transferred him to another school. I called the boys in school and questioned them concerning their disobedience. Basil said: "I did not hear Donald."
I was in the toilet."
Fred said: "John told us not to stack wood."
Robert said: "I was playing with the little ones. I didn't hear."
Jack said: "Nobody was going to stack, so I didn't."
Sam said: "John told the boys not to stack wood."
Donald said: "John said, don't do anything. Mr. Jolley tells you. He won't thrash you, so it doesn't matter."

I then questioned Fred, Sam, Jack and Donald as to why they obeyed John. They told me that they were scared of John.

I then asked why they were scared of John. He is of medium height and fat, but of no great physical strength and they have rarely been knocked out by him when boxing. Sam said, "We are not scared of John so much. We are scared of his father." Now sir, John's father is the medicine.
man and purveyor of evil spirits for this reserve.

To find that this illiterate dealer in evil spirits was undermining the morale of my Scouts was more than I could tolerate. So, on Saturday, Feb. 27th, I broke up a visit to Mr. and Mrs. Matley to visit the Agent. I arrived about 11 a.m., but he was not in his office. I went to the house, and gave him a full account of the incidents which led to my sending John home. I begged him to arrange John as speedily as possible. He said that he (the Agent) would come to the reserve as soon as he could.

However, I took a very severe cold. On Sunday I went to church at Kutsawa and then to dinner with Mr. E.J. Howes. I was overcome while there and we were forced to remain overnight. We came home on Monday morning.
and I was in bed until Saturday morning. The following Monday I opened school and found that several children had measles. I sent a telephone message to the doctor.

On Tuesday March 9th the doctor visited re measles and the agent re John Kapaay. To my amazement I heard that nothing had been done concerning the removal of this boy. John was at home supposedly sick. The agent told me that he would go to see the family and would have John back in school. Most emphatically I said, "No, sir, he has done so much mischief already, that I would rather leave the school than have John return."

On March 15th John Kapaay presented himself. I asked, "Why are you here?"— "I've come to school." "Go home until Mr. Moore comes for you." John went home. The same evening the boys...
brother James came to the house and said that Mr. Moore had told John to come to school. I ignored this, for I had (before Christmas) asked Mr. Moore to refrain from sending oral messages by Indians, for I had received several messages purporting to come from Mr. Moore which were untruths. Then, this morning, I received this letter of which I am enclosing a copy. I have sent the boy home, for I am convinced that if he returns I may as well give up all hope of teaching anything, either secular or religious, to the children on this reserve.

As I told the Agent, I would rather retire now, with a seventeen years' teaching reputation unsullied, than wait until John had done his worst and then retire under a cloud.

I am sorry to have to
trouble you, but we have had such unfortunate experiences of Indian Department officials that I feel that this attitude on the part of the Agent should not be dismissed lightly.

Since John was sent home, the boys have returned to their Scout spirit and are looking round for things to do for Mr. Jolley and myself.

Yours truly,

L. M. Jolley.

Hon. and Dear Sir,

I am enclosing a copy of the statement which I have forwarded to B. Hjalmarson, Esq., Inspector of Public Schools, Wynyard, Sask.; and a copy of the Indian Agent's letter.

The work on this reserve has suffered during the past year from interference by officials. Dating from May 1925, Mr. Jolley and I have heard much adverse criticism of the conduct of the work on this reserve.

On May 5th, we were visited by a woman known as Miss Brandt who introduced herself as a nurse employed by the Indian Department.
She made herself most unpleasant to school children, Mr. Jolley and myself. Although she acknowledged that she had never before visited the reserves in this Agency, yet she displayed a remarkable knowledge of the conduct of this school and Agency during the residence of my predecessors.

One wonders from whom this nurse obtained her information. When the children returned to school after the summer vacation they were very dirty. I allowed them three weeks to recover from the effects of their holiday, but my daily lesson of "hygiene" seemed of no avail. I visited the parents, asking them to clean up their children. Several women were rather rude. They told me that my predecessor did not bother about their children's heads, so why should I?

Again one wonders whom was the person who prompted such a remark.
I outlined the case to the Indian Inspector. He informed me that I was exceeding my duty to talk to these women concerning these children—"That is the Agent's job. He has more pull than you have with the Indians"—This official concluded by ordering the Agent to "Go to David Stoir, take the nurse with you, and tell them Indians to keep their darn kids clean or they will be sent to boarding school." I was really so disgusted that my husband had much difficulty in restraining me from sending you a report at the time the incident occurred.

During the school term from April until June 30th, 1925, Mr. Jolley or I drove on four occasions five miles to send telephone messages to the school. Two of these messages reached the closing of the school for one day. None of these messages were delivered.
by the clerk to the Agent. Is this business-like conduct of an office? Concerning the visit of the nurse, I asked my husband to write our Bishop—As far as we are concerned I believe that this matter has been settled.

With regard to the remarks of the Indian Inspector re dirty children, I conversed with the Inspector of Public Schools on this subject, and he was very surprised at the attitude of the Indian Inspector, for as Mr. Palmer (J.P.S.) remarked "Without the daily cooperation of the teachers, very little could be done by nurses or any other officials."

Further, on September 8th, the Indian Agent suggested that we assist him by allowing the five senior boys to excavate the cellar. He impressed on us that the Indian Department had apportioned $15.00 (fifteen dollars) for this work. He approved the plan that $10.00 (ten dollars) should be paid for lumber for supports and shelves and $5.00 (five dollars) for labor. Mr. Jolley
and I spoke to the boys concerning this work. We offered them three meals each day that they worked; the work to be done in school hours; and $1.50 (one dollar) each in cash at completion. We also told them that the work would probably take four or five days. They talked it over, and agreed to the terms. The work took four days, during which time Mr. Jolley supervised, allowing frequent rest periods. When finished I wrote asking Agent for money to pay the boys. No payment was forthcoming and this bred discontent.

Edwin Kinequon voiced this discontent to the Indian Inspector during the week ending September 26th. Without consulting us the Indian Inspector told Edwin Kinequon that the boys should receive $2.00 (two dollars) payment. This seemed to me a scandalous proceeding for—apart from the fact that these boys had three ample meals each day that they worked—this Inspector was encouraging these boys to break a contract entered into by them willingly, having full knowledge of the duration and
nature of the work. How can one be expected to inculcate qualities of obedience, respect, and a spirit of fair play into the minds and life of these boys in face of such opposition from an official of the Indian Department?

The Indian Department insists upon teachers in Day Schools being qualified and surely the teachers are entitled to respect and consideration on the part of these local and provincial officials.

During our time of residence on this reserve, Mr. Jolley and I have tried by all means in our power to raise the physical, mental and moral standard of the Indians on this reserve.

The boys were making really good progress as Scouts. Unfortunately, the events aforementioned have seriously interfered with the Scout work, thereby causing us much disappointment.

Might I respectfully submit the following: That teachers in Indian Day Schools be responsible only
to three persons at most. The white schools of the province are very successfully managed by a board of three trustees; sometimes only one official trustee.

I have repeatedly asked for urgent repairs and redecoration of house and school. So far nothing has been done with regard to the school building and very little to the house. These buildings are a disgrace—especially so to a Government department. Yet the report of the school teacher and Inspector of Public Schools is not sufficient.

The teacher must report to the Indian Agent. The Indian Agent must report to the Indian Inspector. The Indian Inspector reports to the Indian Commissioner. The Indian Commissioner reports to the Minister of Indian Affairs.

By the time the report reaches the Minister, nothing, apparently, is required.

I fully realize that no blame should be attached to the Minister. Therefore, Hon. Sir, I bring
these facts to your notice. The condition of these buildings is adversely commented upon by visitors. Most of the visitors have no local prejudice. Mr. Cowper of the Topographical Survey Department will bear witness to the abovementioned facts re the condition of the buildings.

I trust, Hon. Sir, that you will give the subjects mentioned in my letter your careful consideration with a view to making the lot of the teachers in Indian Day Schools rather more pleasant and congenial, and with a view to preventing so much overlapping and officialdom in the administration of Indian Day Schools.

This is not the complaint of a child, but of one who has seventeen years professional experience to her credit, and who has never before known so many officials to be necessary in the educating of fifteen children.

I remain, Hon. Sir,

Yours respectfully,

L. M. Jolley (Mrs. J. Jolley)
