Your letter #121-2-1 of the 20th September last stated that this teacher could have leave for one month in case he was sick. You will note from his written remarks on the above return that he is in hospital. He thinks he will be back to work on November 1st next but I understand from other sources that he may never leave the hospital till they carry him out in a coffin as he is a very sick man.

Under the circumstances I think it would be advisable for the Department to request the Bishop to be ready to have a new teacher take over at this point on November 1st. Mrs Watts came back here and packed up all her furniture last week so she thinks she will be moving away.

I understand that Mr Watts got $50.00 per annum salary less 10%, and Mrs Watts got $50.00 per annum for issuing rations and drugs, and $5.00 per month during school term for her work as janitor in the school.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, October 11, 1933.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 4th instant, with reference to the teacher of the Day Star Indian Day School. While it appears from your letter that it is very unlikely that Rev. Mr. Watts will be able to resume duties as teacher at this school, I would appreciate your making enquiry and advising the Department as soon as you have more information. Before making arrangements for a new teacher, we want to be absolutely certain that Mr. Watts will not be able to again take charge of the school.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

J. W. Waddy, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Punnichy, Sask.
Sir:

I am advised by Agent Waddy that he has reported to the Department the condition of the Reverend H. G. L. Watts, Teacher at the Day Star Day School. It has become necessary that Mr. Watts should be absent for at least one month in order to undergo an operation.

The Reverend Archdeacon Knowles has conferred with me regarding Mr. Watts' condition and also as to the advisability of providing a substitute teacher during his absence. The Archdeacon, Mr. Waddy, and myself are of the opinion that it is not necessary to have a substitute until it is ascertained that Mr. Watts may not be able to take up his duties again. There is no place for a substitute teacher to live and I am told that Mrs. Watts strongly objects to have anyone occupying her home during her absence. I trust the Department will approve of keeping the school closed temporarily until we know the outcome of Mr. Watts' operation.

Your obedient servant,

W. Murison,
Inspector,
Saskatchewan Inspectorate.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Dear Sir;-

In further reference to your letter #121-2-1 of September 20th last regarding leave of absence for Rev H.G.L. Watts, the teacher of the day school on the Day Star Indian Reserve, I beg to report that I am in receipt of a letter from Mr. Watts stating that prospects of his returning to work at the end of October are negative, and he asks me to apply to the Department to extend his leave of absence until November 30th next.

His leave to October 31st with pay is granted in your letter, and I beg to recommend that he be allowed leave until November 30th next, the question of pay for November to be decided by regulations made by the Department.

In order that the Department may know where this gentleman is located I beg to say his address is "The General Hospital, Toronto, Ont."

It will be seen from the many reports I sent in on the work of Mr. Watts that he was one of the best day school teachers to come to my notice.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent

Ottawa, October 17, 1933.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 13th instant, relative to the condition of the Rev. H. G. L. Watts, teacher of the Day Star Indian Day School. The Department has also received a communication from Mr. Agent Waddy, stating that the prospects for his returning to work at the end of October are negative. He requests an extension of Mr. Watts' leave of absence until the end of November, next.

In this connection I have to say that it will not be necessary to provide a substitute teacher during his absence. This school may be closed, temporarily, until we know the outcome of Mr. Watts' operation. I would request that you inform Mr. Agent Waddy accordingly.

I may add it is hoped that Mr. Watts will be able to resume duties on or about the first of December, next, and I shall be pleased to have a further report from you regarding his condition, stating if he will be able to resume duties before the end of the current year.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Dear Sir;-

In reference to your letter #121-2-1 of the 11th inst asking if I am definitely certain that Rev. Mr Watts will not resume his duties as teacher of the day school at Day Star Reserve, I beg to say that taking his letters and information given me by his wife I was absolutely certain until yesterday that he would not resume his duties; however, yesterday he got off the train here saying that the doctors had given him another lease of life that he had not been operated on but that he was not well but would resume his duties on November first next if he is strong enough. I will let the Department know what develops, if Mr. Watts gets well enough to teach again I will be very pleased.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent

The Secretary,

Ottawa.
Ottawa, October 23, 1933.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 17th instant, informing the Department that Rev. Mr. Watts would probably resume duties as teacher of the Day Star Indian Day School on the first proxime. In this connection I have to say that a communication was received from Mr. Inspector Murison, who had received a letter from Mr. Watts, stating that the prospects for his returning to work at the end of the present month were negative, and he requested an extension of his leave of absence until the first of December, next. Mr. Murison was informed that the school might be closed temporarily until the end of November, if Mr. Watts was not able to resume duties before that time. However, if his health now permits him to return to work, he should re-open the school as soon as possible.

It is noted that you will inform the Department regarding developments, stating if Mr. Watts' health permits him to teach again and the date he begins duties. In any event, it will not be necessary to provide a substitute teacher before the first of December, at which time you should be in a position to state definitely whether Mr. Watts is able to continue the work.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

J. W. Waddy, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Punnichy, Sask.
Dear Sir;-

In reference to your letter #121-2-1 of October 23rd last and others of same file regards Rev. Mr. Watts the teacher on the Day Star Day School, I beg to say that I was at this school on the 6th inst and found the school in operation, Mr. Watts had resumed his duties on the 1st of November.

It is impossible to say how long his health will allow him to work, he is very frail, but he tells me he might as well be working as not, and that he will keep going as long as possible. I will keep in touch with him constantly and assist him where necessary.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Dear Sir;

In reference to your letter 121-2-1 of the 26th ultimo, regards the appointment of a new teacher for Day Satr Day School, I beg to say that the Bishop of Qu'Appelle has nominated Rev. Francis E. Torpey for the position.

Mr. Torpey is married, aged 46, holds a certificate known as the Oxford Senior. He has not Norman School training. He appears to be a first rate chap, good common sense, and will probably be very suitable.

FORM 14
Ottawa, April 4th, 1928.

Sir,

I beg to inform you that His Lordship the Bishop of Qu'Appelle has nominated Rev. H. G. L. Watts for the position of teacher of the Day Star Indian Day School to begin duties at once. The Department is approving of his appointment, with salary at the rate of $65 per teaching month. I shall be pleased if you will give Mr. Watts any assistance you can upon his taking up duties at this school.

Mrs. Jolley should prepare and forward returns showing the attendance, days taught, etc., up to the period she gave up duties, and this you should forward to the Department, in order that payment of the salary due her can be made.

Yours obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

S. S. Moore, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Punnichy, Sask.
Ottawa, July 11th, 1928.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of the June quarter return of the Day Stars Indian Day School.

If you refer to official letter of April 4th last, you will note that the Department requested that the return should show what period, if any, Mrs. Jolley taught this school during the June quarter. Please let me know on what date Mr. Watts began duties at this school and, also, if Mrs. Jolley taught the school for any part of the quarter. On receipt of this information, payment of salary will be made.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Russell T. Perrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

S. S. Moore, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Pumichy, Sask.
Touchwood Agency, Punnichy, Sask.
July 16th, 1928.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter No. 121-2-3 of the 11th instant, I beg to report that Mrs. Jolley did not teach at the Day Star school for any part of the June quarter. Mr. Watts moved out to the school on April 10th, but he did not open school until April 16th, as he was quite sick with an attack of influenza.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

The Secretary,
Indian Agent,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,

March 29, 1944.

Reverend T.R. Taylor, Teacher, Day Star Indian Day School, Punnichy, Sask.

I have your letter of the 25th instant, with reference to your return showing the attendance at the Day Star School. I do not see how you made the mistake of preparing a return for the months of September, October and November. Please note instruction number 7 on the front page of the day school return. This reads as follows:

"The Quarterly Returns must end on the 31st March, 30th June, 30th September, and 31st December respectively, and be immediately thereafter in each case transmitted to the local Indian Agent."

The above means that at the end of September a return is prepared for the one month and at the end of the other three quarters a return is prepared for a period of three months.

Philip Phelan,

$40.00 was placed in the last Estimated to provide for a fence around the grounds at the Day Star School and, with an additional $50.00, I think we could get the Indians to put up a log barn for the teacher, and this would also take care of the window in the basement.

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF MR. INSPECTOR HAMILTON, DATED APRIL 19TH, 1929, ON HIS INSPECTION OF THE DAY STAR INDIAN DAY SCHOOL.

A noon-day meal is supplied for the children and this is prepared by Mrs. Watts and served in the basement of the school. However, this is very unsatisfactory as the basement is only 10 x 12, and the furnace takes up most of the room. An addition built to the kitchen of the teacher's residence would make a much more suitable dining room for the children and would make the work easier for Mrs. Watts. This room would not need to be more than 10 x 12 and would not entail any great expense. There is no fence surrounding the school grounds and it is very discouraging to try to grow a garden when it is impossible to keep the stock away. These grounds and the garden should be fenced, which would also greatly add to the appearance of the place.

Trouble was experienced this spring by the water getting into the basement of the school. I found that the only window in the basement is partly below the ground level and consequently the water runs in around the window. This could be remedied by digging down and placing a cement wall about a foot away from the window allowing this wall to come up above the level of the ground. It will require possibly a couple of bags of cement.

There is no barn at this school, consequently, Mr. Watts is unable to keep a horse or cow and is obliged to depend on the Indians when he wishes to leave the reserve. This is very unsatisfactory and a small barn 12 x 14 would meet the requirements.
Sir—

I have received a letter from the Reverend H.G.L. Watts, teacher at the Bay Star day school, asking if the Department would secure, free of charge, from the Ontario Government Picture Bureau some films which he can utilize to give picture shows on the reserve from time to time. He informs me that the films cost from .25¢ to .50¢ a reel, depending on its nature. He has been having these picture shows for some time, having purchased a moving picture outfit at a cost of $225.00 and he thinks that an occasional gathering of Indians on the reserve will help to break them away from their "old pow wows". The style of films that he suggests are varied and he says they should cover sport, travel, hunting, manners and customs, industry, forestry, and agriculture, and thinks that these will have an educational value. He states that the cost to him of having one of these picture shows is about $10.00 to $12.00 an evening.

Will the Department advise me whether it would consider Mr. Watts' proposal.

Your obedient servant,

W.M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 19th instant, the Department has already ordered 550 lbs. biscuits for the Fishing Lake School, and 450 lbs. biscuits for the Day Star Indian Day School.

The Department wishes to be as generous as possible regarding the mid-day meals, but at the same time, our funds are limited, and under these circumstances we cannot allow as large an amount as requested by the teachers of these two schools. Last year we allowed $60 at Fishing Lake, and the same amount will be available this year.

At Day Star School we only allowed $40.00 last year, and the same amount can be expended this year.

Yours very truly,

Philip Phelan
Chief, Training Division

Indian Agent,

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of a letter from Mr. Waddy in which he states that the well at Day Star Day School, Touchwood Agency, is going dry. This is the source of the water supply for the School and Teacher's Residence. He states that until last year they got about 14 pails of water from the well before it was dry, then it took some hours to fill again. Last Fall it got down to 10 pails, this Spring to 6 pails, and now they get 1½ pails and then have to wait all day before they can get any more.

He states the well is 60 feet deep, and it looks as though it has drained all the water out of the local area. It is his opinion that a new well, some distance away, at a similar depth, might get water, although there is no assurance that it would. He states the cost would be approximately $125.00, and asks if he may have authority to proceed with the work.

If funds are available, I would recommend that Mr. Waddy's request be acceded to.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Thos. Robertson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

Dear Sir,

I am writing you in regard to the sewing machine belonging to the school. This machine is very old and is completely worn out, and cannot be used any more. We are in very bad need of a new one to take its place. This is particularly needed this year as we now have eleven girls among our enrollment.

As you are aware Mrs Torpey teaches the girls, among other things, to make clothes for themselves &c. This includes both hand and machine sewing, and also the proper care of a sewing machine. The girls are very apt pupils in this subject, and as you know, have turned out some really good work. The dresses worn by the girls when they went to Touchwood last June to see the King and Queen, were all made by the girls themselves. You will agree, I think that this is something which is of real value to the girls after they have left school. I should be glad therefore if you would forward this request for a new sewing machine to the Department.

I am,
Yours faithfully,

F. E. Torpey

Dear Sir:

Agent Waddy advised me on September 26th that the well at the Day Star School is practically dry and the children can only obtain a lard pail of water at one hour intervals. He states that the well was dug two years ago and wasn't quite satisfactory at the beginning, with only 3 ft. of water.

Dear Sir:

There is an Indian day school on the Day Star Indian Reserve in the Province of Saskatchewan. This is located in Township 30, Range 16, west of the Second Meridian. Two years ago a well was dug to a depth of 60 feet but it is now practically dry and a request has been received for authority to dig a new well. Have you any information indicating if there is any likelihood of securing a plentiful supply of water in the neighbourhood mentioned? If so, please let me know to what depth you consider a well should be dug.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mines & Geology Branch,

Victoria Memorial Museum,

Mr. R.E. Hoey,
Superintendent of Welfare
and Training, Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

With reference to your inquiry concerning the probability of getting a good supply of water near the Indian day school on the Day Star Reserve in Saskatchewan, I may say that the chances of getting a good supply are only fair, anywhere in that area.

The water occurs in irregularly distributed porous zones in the glacial drift in that area. The glacial drift may be as much as 250 feet thick in places. To try another well in the immediate vicinity would probably only yield the same results as the present well. It might be better to deepen the present well by drilling. The chances are fair that water may be reached within 200 feet. No good supplies of water are obtained in the bedrock formations below the glacial drift in this area and drilling should not be carried deeper than the top of the bedrock. The bedrock is a tough grey shale without pebbles or stones.

If there is any doubt about the identification of the material we will be glad to identify any samples sent to us.

Yours truly,

R.T.D. Wickenden
Officer in Charge,
Ground Water and Borings Section,

EXTRACT FROM LETTER FROM M. CHRISTIANSON,
General Supt. of Indian Agencies, REGINA, Sask.,
dated July 24, 1941.

Both the teacher's residence and the school are in good state of repair, and the same applies to the grounds. However, the water situation is a real problem here. I believe a 60 ft. well was put down about five years ago and this has gone practically dry. The only way water can be obtained from the well is by drawing it with a small pail as there isn't sufficient water left to use the pump. In my opinion, whether Mr. Torpey comes back or not, someone will be there and a new well should be put down. No doubt they will find water at about the same depth, 60 ft., and this would cost $1.50 per ft. or about $125.00.
Mr J.W.Waddy,
Indian Agent,
Funnichy, Sask.

AIR MAIL

Dear Sir:

The well at the Day Star School on the Day Star Reserve has gone dry and I have authorized Agent Waddy to engage an Indian to haul water by barrel at a cost of $10.00 per month. In the meantime it will be necessary to dig a well for this School.

Mr. Waddy informs me that Mr. McRobbie, a well driller, has just moved his outfit on the Poorman Reserve to dig a well there. [Mr. McRobbie] has made the same offer to Mr. Waddy to dig a well on the Day Star Reserve at the price of $225.00 plus cribbing estimated to cost $50.00. In this case the understanding is similar to that in connection with the Poorman Reserve, that is, if no water is found Mr. McRobbie will not be paid.

On the other hand Mr. McRobbie will dig a well for $1.50 per ft. plus cribbing. This might be the cheaper deal because from past experience it is found that water is obtained on the Day Star Reserve at a depth of between 60 and 80 ft. The last well drilled there was 70 ft. in depth, at which point a rock was struck and the machine could not go down any further. It might be advisable to take this matter up with the Engineering Branch as there is some assurance of getting water at this depth and the rate per ft. will be the best way of drilling it as it would cost us around $100.00 more or less, plus cribbing.

As stated above, since Mr. McRobbie has just started on Poorman Reserve he will be prepared to move on to Day Star immediately after and I would therefore request that this matter be dealt with immediately and I be advised by Air Mail of the Department's decision.

Yours truly,

M. Christianson,
General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.

There is a tank full of water in the basement of the school which will have to be baled out before the cold weather sets in unless a teacher is appointed. I can get an Indian to put fires on in the school for $6.00 a month if you will give me the authority, which will prevent the tank freezing.

Your obedient servant

R.S. Davis
Indian Agent

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 29th ultimo, the Department recently wrote to the Bishop with a view to having him nominate a teacher for the Day Star Indian Day School. A reply should be received some time this month and we will likely be in a position to know by the end of November if we are going to secure a teacher. If it is necessary to keep the building heated during the month of November, in order to avoid freezing the water in the tank in the basement, you may incur the necessary expenditure mentioned in your letter. However, if we do not secure a teacher by the end of November I believe that the tank should be drained, as it appears undesirable to continue the expenditure for wood the whole winter simply to keep the water in the tank from freezing.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Regina, November 17th 1944.

I am attaching a requisition I have received from Agent Davis for a new pump and cylinder. This is for the well at the Day Star Indian Day School.

Mr. Davis informs me that the pump there is old and broken down and it is very hard to pump water from a well that is 65' deep. He actually wanted a double action pump so as to make the pumping easier but upon enquiring here we find that double action pumps are not on the market. Besides they are of the opinion that the double action pump is harder to handle in a deep well. It was therefore suggested that a $25" cylinder with a 1½" pipe be furnished. The price is $24.95 for the cylinder and pump head as quoted by McPherson and Thom who are agents for the Ontario Wind Engine and Pump Company.

With reference to the pipes Mr. Davis was unable to give us the size of the present ones that are being used. However, he said it does not matter what size the pipes required are as he will attend to that. Therefore he has not asked for pipes for the cylinder but I would think that he will require piping as well and the prices quoted were for galvanized pipes at $.24 per ft. As for the rods he can use those at present in use.

M. Christianson,
General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.

Regina, April 13th, 1945.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

Re: Yours No. 121-2-5 of November 22nd,
Pump for the Day Star Day School.

I am attaching our voucher in favour of McPherson & Thom Company for a pump and cylinder for the above mentioned day school.

The reason that this is so late is that we had difficulty in getting a pump. However, we succeeded in procuring one last February and it was shipped out by McPherson & Thom just a couple of days ago.

We are sending you voucher from this office so as to get it to Ottawa in time to be paid from this year's Appropriation. I am notifying Mr. Davis of the action being taken and sending him a copy of the invoice from the firm which supplied the pump.

I trust that you will find this in order for payment.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Acting Inspector of Indian Agencies.

QUARTERLY REPORT ENDING JUNE 30th, 1945, ON TOUCHWOOD AGENCY

DAY STAR SCHOOL

The attendance to this school has been very good. The teacher has three parishes outside the reserve to look after as well as the school and naturally hasn't the time to take the interest in the school he should. He is very sloppy around the building & not fitted for the work. However a change will be made as Mr. Taylor is leaving.

Considerable repairs will have to be done at this place and I am taking this matter up in a separate letter.

EX'D.

R.S. Davis,
Indian Agent.
